abstract.text: Configure pieces of an AVCaptureSession to capture video in Apple ProRes.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: TN3104: Recording video in Apple ProRes

inlineContent.text: iPhone 13 Pro supports Apple ProRes video recording up to 4k at 30 fps and 1080p at 60 fps (except the 128GB model, which supports Apple ProRes video recording up to 1080p at 30 fps).
This Technote details how to configure an AVCapture pipeline to capture and record a video encoded in Apple ProRes 422.
For a general overview of Apple ProRes codecs, see
Capturing video in Apple ProRes requires manual configuration of the
’s
There is no
available that supports capture in Apple ProRes.
For this reason, set the
of your
to
, which specifies that the
should not automatically configure its inputs and outputs.
As described in
, Apple ProRes 422 codecs require 10-bits-per-channel video sources, and Apple ProRes 4444 codecs support up to 12-bits-per-channel and up to 16 bits for the alpha channel.
If you iterated through all of the supported capture
of an
on iPhone 13 Pro, you would see capture formats with one of the following pixel formats:
Pixel Format Constant
FourCharCode
Bits Per Channel
kCVPixelFormatType_420YpCbCr8BiPlanarVideoRange
kCVPixelFormatType_420YpCbCr8BiPlanarFullRange
kCVPixelFormatType_420YpCbCr10BiPlanarVideoRange
kCVPixelFormatType_422YpCbCr10BiPlanarVideoRange

Notice that there are no supported capture formats that capture at higher than 10-bits-per-channel, also notice that none of the supported capture formats use a 4:4:4 pixel format. Therefore, none of the capture formats output video data that is suitable as a video source for Apple ProRes 4444 codecs.
To find a capture format that is suitable as a video source for an Apple ProRes 422 codec, you should iterate through the capture
of the
, and return a capture format whose
is

code: // Iterate over the supported capture formats.
// Check if the captureFormat's pixel format is equivalent to the target pixel format.
// Check if other criteria is met.  For example, you may want to target a particular resolution or max frame rate.
// Once all criteria is met, return the current format.
// If there is no supported capture format that meets the selection criteria, return nil. Your app may wish to fallback to some other capture format in this case.

inlineContent.text: Once you have identified a capture format suitable for Apple ProRes 422, set it as the
of your capture device, and ensure that the capture device has a corresponding
which you have successfully added as an input to the
See
for more information about adding inputs to a capture session.
For many apps, using an
to write an Apple ProRes movie file is sufficient.
If you require a greater amount of control when writing the movie file, or you need access to video samples before they are written to a movie file, then you can use an
to get access to the video samples. Next, you can process or inspect the video samples, and then submit the video samples to an
supports writing movie files encoded with Apple ProRes 422 codecs.
To check the available video codecs at runtime, you can iterate through the
The
array is dynamic, and depends on the
of the
that is connected to the same
as the
For this reason, you should check for support of Apple ProRes 422 codecs only after you have configured the capture device to capture in an ‘x422’ format.
Once you have verified that the movie file output supports your desired Apple ProRes 422 codec, use the
method to set specify the codec that the output should use:

code: // Ensure that the availableVideoCodecTypes contains the target codec.
}) else { fatalError("Target codec is not supported in the current configuration.") }
fatalError("The movie file output is not connected to a video input.")
// Set the output settings of the movieFileOutput.

inlineContent.text: does not require any special configuration to be compatible with an ‘x422’ input, simply set its sample buffer delegate with the
method, and add the output to the capture session.
Use the
method to set a recording delegate and start recording to a file.
When recording is stopped, you will receive the output file in
You can save this movie file directly to the Photo Library using the
method.
Once saved, you can view the video in the Photos app, where you will notice that the asset has a “ProRes” badge in the upper-left corner.

content.text: Recording and saving with AVCaptureVideoDataOuput and AVAssetWriter

inlineContent.text: Once you have decided to start recording, create an
, and an
. When you create the
, specify outputSettings that use your preferred Apple ProRes 422 video codec. You can request recommended settings from the

code: // Request the recommended video settings for your target codec.
// Use the video settings to initialize your video input for writing.
// Specify that you have a real-time video sample source.
// Create the AVAssetWriter using your outputURL.
assetWriter = try AVAssetWriter(outputURL: outputURL, fileType: fileType)
// Add the video input to the asset writer.

inlineContent.text: Take the video samples that you receive in the
delegate method and append them to your movie file

code: // Start the asset writer if it hasn't been started already, and use the first sampleBuffer's presentationTimeStamp as the source time.
// Append the sample buffer if the video input is ready.

inlineContent.text: When you decide to stop recording, call
. In the completion handler, you can save the movie file directly to the Photo Library using the
method, passing in the
of the asset writer.
Once saved, you can view the video in the Photos app, where you will notice that the asset has a “ProRes” badge in the upper-left corner.

abstract.text: An object that writes media data to a container file.
Marks all unfinished inputs as finished and completes the writing of the output file.
The location of the container file that the writer outputs.
An object that appends media samples to a track in an asset writer’s output file.
An object that represents a hardware or virtual capture device like a camera or microphone.
The capture format in use by the device.
The capture formats a device supports.
An object that provides media input from a capture device to a capture session.
Starts recording media to the specified output URL.
Informs the delegate when all pending data has been written to an output file.
A capture output that records video and audio to a QuickTime movie file.
The video codecs types the output supports for recording movie files.
Returns the settings the output uses to encode media from the specified connection.
An object that configures capture behavior and coordinates the flow of data from input devices to capture outputs.
Presets that define standard configurations for a capture session.
A preset that doesn’t specify audio and video output settings for a capture session.
A preset value that indicates the quality level or bit rate of the output.
A capture output that records video and provides access to video frames for processing.
Sets the sample buffer delegate and the queue for invoking callbacks.
Notifies the delegate that a new video frame was written.
Configure input devices, output media, preview views, and basic settings before capturing photos or video.
The media subtype.
Creates a request for adding a new video asset to the Photos library, using the video file at the specified URL.
